document.docAuthor: Parapar, Julio, Moreira, Juan & Helgason, Gudmundur Vidir
document.docTitle: Orbiniella petersenae Parapar, Moreira & Helgason, 2015, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: First record of genus Orbiniella Day, 1954 (Polychaeta: Orbiniidae) in North Atlantic Ocean with the description of a new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First record of genus Orbiniella Day, 1954 (Polychaeta: Orbiniidae) in North Atlantic Ocean with the description of a new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. A total of
222 specimens
of
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
were collected.
Holotype
: IINH 35670 (BIOICE sample 3636 ; 1,844−1,849 m depth, incomplete specimen).
Paratypes :
IINH 29795 (BIOICE sample 2430 ; 1,007−1,016 m ; 26 spec.); IINH 34892 (BIOICE sample 2444 ; 133−148 m ; 2 spec.); IINH 34894 (BIOICE sample 3611 ; 188−197 m ; 16 spec. EtOH fixed); IINH 35669 (BIOICE sample 3632 ;
6 specimens
on SEM stub); IINH 35671 ( BIOCE sample 3636 ; 1,844−1,849 m ; 94 spec.); IINH 35672 ( BIOCE sample 3636 ; 1 posterior end;); MNCN 16.01 / 16549 (BIOICE sample 3636 ; 19 paratypes ); IINH 29822 (BIOICE sample 3640 ; 1,908−1,915 m ; 46 spec.); IINH 34897 (BIOICE sample 3640 ; 1 posterior end on SEM stub); IINH 35673 (BIOICE sample 3640 ;
3 specimens
imaged with µCT); IINH 34899 (BIOICE sample 3656 ; 1,490−1,492 m ; 9 spec.; EtOH fixed).

Description of holotype .
Anterior fragment, body of uniform width, 6 .0 mm long, 0.3 mm wide at level of first chaetiger, with 25 chaetigers; no body external regionalization (
Fig. 3
A), lacking pigmentation. Prostomium rounded, wider than long (
Fig. 3
B–C), provided with two dorsal brownish semi-lunar patches (diffuse photoreception area with ocelli?). No conspicuous nuchal organs observed. Two achaetous peristomial annuli, first narrower than second, distinctly separated from first chaetiger (
Fig. 3
B–C). From CH 9 onwards segments becoming longer, more square-shaped (
Fig. 3
A). Segment annulation not clear under light microscope (but see SEM observations of paratypes below).

Notopodia with small, postchaetal papilla present from CH 1 , sometimes located in between the two parapodial rami; papilla absent in neuropodia (
Fig. 3
B and also see SEM micrographs of paratypes :
Figs 4
A, 5 C, 6 C, E). Notopodia and neuropodia bearing each 7–10 long crenulated capillaries and 1–3 short, stout smooth aciculae (
Fig. 3
C and also see SEM micrographs of paratypes :
Figs 5
C–F, 6 C, E); capillary chaetae with crenulation occurring on one side along half length. Capillaries in first segments longer than body width (
Fig. 3
B).

Variation. The study of paratypes under stereomicroscope and SEM allowed elucidating the structure and range of variability of some body features. The species shows great body fragility; despite the high number of specimens obtained, none was complete. Longer anterior fragments are of about 23 chaetigers.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2. Illustrations of described species of
Orbiniella
sorted by date of original description (redrawn from Day 1954; Hartman 1967; Hobson 1974; Blake 1985; Blake & Hilbig 1990; Buzhinskaja 1993; Branch 1998; Gillet 1999; Narayawasmany & Blake 2005).
Orbiniella uniformis
was not illustrated by Hartman (1967),
Falklandiella annulata Hartman, 1967
is currently considered as likely member of genus
Orbiniella
.
Orbiniella branchiata
and
O. drakei
are probably not members of
Orbiniella
(see Discussion).

FIGURE 3.
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
A–C, Holotype IINH 35670; D–E, Paratype IINH 35672. A, dorsal view (chaetae not illustrated); B, anterior end, dorsal view; C, anterior end, ventral view; D, posterior end, dorsal view; E, posterior end, ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
SEM micrographs showed lateral ciliary spots at both sides of prostomium (
Fig. 4
E–F), which might represent nuchal organs (see Discussion). Annulation of segments between parapodial rami follows this pattern: one ring between CH 1 and CH 2 , two rings between CH 2 – CH 6 ( 5 ) and three rings from CH 6 ( 5 ) (
Figs 4
A–D, 5 A–B); annulation is less defined in pre-pygidial region (
Fig. 6
D). Annulation is lost when segments are conspicuously elongated (
Fig. 6
A–B). Notopodial papilla is always present from CH 1 (
Fig. 5
C). Neuropodial papilla was not observed. Capillary and acicular chaetae are present in both rami from CH 1 (
Fig. 5
C–F). Capillaries are long and numerous ( 9–10 per bundle) in the first 5–6 chaetigers (
Fig. 4
A, C); acicular chaetae numbering up to 3 per rami.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
SEM micrographs of paratypes IINH 35669. A–B, anterior end, dorsal view; C–E, anterior end, ventral view; F, detail of right lateral side of prostomium showing ciliature (insert of E).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Last 5–6 posterior segments suddenly become much shorter acquiring a crowded appearance (
Fig. 6
A, D); these look achaetous but show small lateral projections (= small parapodia;
Fig. 6
D, black arrowhead). In some cases, body shows an inflated region just before the pygidium (see
Blake 1985
) which is probably a fixation artefact (
Fig. 2
F). The pygidium is provided with four lobes (
Figs 3
D–E, 6 D, F).

Gross internal anatomy. The study of three paratypes ( IINH 35673 ) under the µCT allowed exploring for the first time the gross internal anatomy of any species of the genus
Orbiniella
(
Figs. 7–9
). The main findings were: ( 1 ) Body general cavity is well separated by septa (
Figs 7
A, 8 A, 9 A, C), and is mostly filled by the digestive system (
Figs 7
B, 8 A, 9 B) and maturing sexual cells (oocytes) (
Figs 7
A–C, 8 A, C–D, 9 B, E–F). ( 2 ) Digestive system shows conspicuous regionalization (
Figs 7
B, 9 B) and is suspended by developed dorsal and ventral mesenteries (
Fig. 9
E):

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
SEM micrographs of paratypes IINH 35669. A, detail of CH5 and CH6, ventral view showing two annuli between chaetal bundles; B, CH8 and CH9, ventral view, showing three annuli between chaetal bundles; C, notopodia of CH3, upper view showing notopodial papilla; D, notopodia of CH5 showing capillary and acicular chaetae; E–F, detail of crenulated chaetae showing rows of small teeth on cutting side.

FIGURE 6.
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
SEM micrographs of paratype IINH 34897. A, posterior end, dorsal view; B, detail of last elongated chaetigers (large insert in A); C, detail of one of the last well developed parapodia showing acicular and capillary chaetae (small insert in A); D, posterior pre-pygidial region with crowded chaetigers (black arrowhead showing first segment with parapodium; white arrowhead showing a segment still without parapodium); E, first reduced chaetigers of prepygidial region showing acicular chaetae and notopodial cirrus (lower insert in D); F, pygidium showing four lobes (upper insert in D).

FIGURE 7.
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
µCT sections of paratype IINH 35673. A, left parasagittal section (dotted lines showing frontal sections showed in B and C); B, mid-body frontal section showing arrangement of the digestive system; C, ventral frontal section showing ventral longitudinal muscle bands and oocytes.

FIGURE 8.
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
µCT sections of paratype IINH 35673. A, left parasagittal section (dotted lines showing transversal sections showed from B to G); B–C, transversal section at foregut (oesophagus) level showing muscles associated with chaetae and coelomic cavity filled of oocytes; D–E, transversal section at midgut (stomach) level (fore and hind stomach respectively) showing its tripartite organization; F–G, transversal section at fore intestine level.

FIGURE 9.
Orbiniella petersenae
sp. nov.
µCT sections of paratype IINH 35673. A, midsagittal section (dotted lines showing frontal sections in B and C, and transversal sections in D and E); B, mid-frontal section at gut level showing arrangement of digestive system (dotted lines showing transversal sections in F and G); C–D, transversal and frontal sections at foregut showing elements of buccal cavity; E–G, transversal sections at oesophagus, fore stomach and fore intestine level.

TABLE 1. Comparison of some relevant characters in the external morphology of described species of
Orbiniella
.

paragraph.emphasis: Species Eyes Nuchal Achaetous segments Segmental annulation Capillary chaetae Preanal Pygidium

subSubSection.paragraph:
.
minuta
Day, 1954
no n.d. buccal segment + biannulated crenulated 0[ 2 ] one pair of rounded lobes
second segment

tr.td: crenulated or camerated 0[2] along the convex edge
first two achaetous segments first two achaetous segments
spine-like 0[n.d.] with transverse rows of 0 3 [0] delicate barbs
bilobed 2 short anal cirri; inflated and unsegmented prepygidial region.
hairy smooth or with teeth 0[0] + plumose and cirrate
first two segments achaetous two peristomial segments
crenulated 1[1] camerated with barbs 0 occurring in two symmetrical rows
rounded with one preanal segment bilobed with two cirriform appendages

subSubSection.paragraph:
Extracted from the drawing because no explicit mention of this character is found in the original description. Data in brackets from
Gillet ( 1999 )
.
“unsegmented pre-pygidial region”.

a. Anterior part (oesophagus) long and narrow, running approximately from anterior end to CH 8 (
Figs 8
A–B, 9 E). Buccal cavity with two dorso-lateral folds and ventral pharyngeal organ.

b. Middle part (stomach) at level of CH 9 and CH 10 (
Figs 8
D–E, 9 F). Stomach trichambered, with dorsal space as prolongation of oesophagus and two defined ventral pouches (lumen not filled with sediment but apparently filled with sort of network); the latter seems to be connected to the stomach lumen at level of hind stomach.

c. Posterior part (intestine) with walls much thicker than those of stomach, running from CH 11 to end of body (
Figs 8
F–G, 9 G).

Most of the digestive tract lumen is filled with sediment including foraminiferans (
Fig. 8
G). ( 3 ) Longitudinal body musculature well developed, organised in two dorsal and two ventral apparent bands ( Figs

7 C, 8 A–G, 9 E–G), also including well defined musculature associated to parapodia and chaetae (
Figs 7
A, C,

Other elements less discernible include dorsal and ventral blood vessels (
Figs 8
E, 9 E–G) and ventral nerve cord (
Figs 8
B, E, 9 E–F).

Etymology. The species is named after Danish polychaetologist Dr. Mary E. Petersen, who has recently passed away. Mary first suggested that these specimens might constitute a new species and her notes and drawings inspired this paper.
